Finding aid created by

did.abstract: Leslie Bassett is a composer and professor of music at the University of Michigan. Bassett’s papers, consisting of correspondence, collected memorabilia, photographs, lectures, scrapbooks, and music, document his career as a composer and professor of music.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Leslie Bassett (donor no. 9672) through Charles Reynolds, U-M Music Library in November 2005.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

The collection contains audio tapes from which digital copies have been made. Source tapes are for staff use only. Audio files are only available in the Bentley Historical Library reading room on designated Bentley Library computers.

userestrict.p: Copyright to his musical compositions is retained by Leslie Bassett; copyright to correspondence has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Leslie Bassett Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

altformavail.p: Digitization: The Library has undertaken the digitization of a number of sound recordings within this collection. The resulting audio files are available for playback only in the Bentley Library Reading Room. Links to item images and additional information are available within this finding aid. Original sound recordings are only available for staff use.

bioghist.p: Leslie Bassett is a composer and professor of music at the University of Michigan. He was born in Hanford, California on January, 23, 1923 and was exposed to music when he first learned to play the piano as a child. In high school, he continued piano and also picked up the trombone. After a few semesters at Fresno State University, he served in World War II in the 13th Armored Division Band of the US Army as a trombonist, but also composed and arranged music.

He earned his Bachelor's degree from Fresno State University in 1947 and then received both his master's degree (1949) and his doctorate (1956) in music composition at the University of Michigan, studying under Ross Lee Finney. In 1950, he was a Fulbright Fellow, studying at the École Normale de Musique in Paris. Bassett began teaching at the University of Michigan in 1952, remaining there until he retired in 1991. While at the University of Michigan, he helped to found the Electronic Music Studio and also headed the Composition Department.

Bassett earned many prizes and awards for his composing and his teaching. Most notably, he won the Pulitzer Prize in Music for Variations for Orchestra in 1966 and in 1984 was named the Henry Russel Lecturer, "the highest honor to be awarded a senior faculty member and the first time that the lectureship had gone to a musician or artist." (Johnson, p.3).

He composed his music for a variety of different instruments and genres including music for orchestra, wind ensemble, chamber music, choral music, brass, solo voice, instrumental solos, organ, piano as well as electronic music.

scopecontent.p: The Leslie Bassett Papers consist of correspondence, collected memorabilia, photographs, lectures, scrapbooks, and musical compositions documenting his career as a composer and professor in the School of Music of the University of Michigan.
This collection contains the following series: Correspondence, Memorabilia, Topical Files, Photographs, Scrapbooks, Sound Recordings, and Compositions.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Composers--United States.
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. School of Music.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (1958-2005, 3.5 linear ft.) is arranged by date, correspondent (name of individual or organization), and topic. Researchers can find both personal correspondence from friends and family as well as professional correspondence detailing different aspects of Bassett's career including music recording and publishing, guest composing, commissions, and awards and fellowships.

did.unittitle: Alfred Publishing Company, Inc./Hinshaw Music, Inc. 1977-2001
League of Composers -- International Society for Contemporary Music (ISCM) 1979
National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities (UM sabbatical leave) 1966-1967
Drawings, cards, and music mostly by Leslie Bassett to his family

scopecontent.p: The Memorabilia series, (1946-2004, 1.5 linear ft.) contains Bassett's collected memorabilia, including articles and clippings as well as programs of music events and performances. Most of the collected programs are from performances at which he conducted or when his music was performed.
The Topical Files (1983-2004, 0.5 linear ft.) series includes interviews of Bassett, several of Bassett's lectures (including his speech as the Henry Russel Lecturer), and various program notes.

did.unittitle: Commencement address for the School of Music, "Great Art Thou, O Music!" 1991
Henry Russel Lecture, "The Shape of Content," 1984
Michigan Orchestra Association on repertory October 13, 1989
University of Michigan Scientific Club, "American Music: some old, some new," 1987
"What are the origins of a new piece of music?" 1967
World Day of Prayer, First Baptist Church, Ann Arbor, "A talk on prayer," February 10, 1967

scopecontent.p: The Photographs (1977-2003, 0.5 linear ft.) document Bassett's personal and professional life, including many photos of family, friends and colleagues as well as photographs of composers, performances, and events.

did.unittitle: American Academy of Arts and Letters, award recipients May 15, 1996
Premiere of "Thoughts that Sing, Breathe, and Burn," February 27-March 1, 1997
Midland (Mich.) Symphony Orchestra, premiere of "Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra," April 30, 1977
Mu Phi Epsilon, 100th year anniversary celebration August 2003
Paul Yeon Lee, Wendoyln Olson, Gabriela Frank at the time of the recording of "Sounds Remembered" for Equilibrium Records 2002
Portraits of Anita and Leslie Bassett

scopecontent.p: The Scrapbooks (1991, 0.5 linear ft.) were compiled for Bassett upon his retirement from the University of Michigan in 1991. The scrapbooks include photographs, cards, letters, programs, and clippings covering his career in music and his time at the University of Michigan.

The Sound Recordings consist of reel-to-reel tapes, cassette tapes, and phonograph discs of Bassett compositions. Some of the recordings are commercially produced; others are recordings of premiere and subsequent performances of his work. In addition, there are a few recordings of some of his public lectures, including his Russel lecture.

accessrestrict.p: [Digitized audio files are only available in the Bentley Historical Library reading room on designated Bentley Library computers.]

scopecontent.p: Bassett's Musical Compositions are arranged into broad classifications: Orchestra Music; Music for Wind Ensemble or Band; Chamber Music; Choral Music; Music for Brass; Music for Solo Voice; Unaccompanied Instrumental Solos; Organ Music; and Piano Music. These categories include only compositions which have been published. These are arranged chronologically by date of composition; copyright date, when known, is included. The kinds of material found within the individual file varies, but can include original manuscripts, publisher's galley proofs, and published score. In addition, this series includes those compositions written for his master of music and doctorate degrees as well as miscellaneous and unpublished musical compositions.

scopecontent.p: The Compositions of others series consists of musical compositions either autographed and inscribed to Leslie Bassett by friends, colleagues, and students or which contain marginal or other notations by Bassett, and which, therefore, might give indication of his method of teaching and/or composition.

relatedmaterial.head: Related resources
relatedmaterial.p: Additional biographical information as well as comprehensive lists of his major works can be found on his personal website at http://www.lesliebassett.com/ and in Ellen Johnson's book Leslie Bassett: a bio-bibliography (1994).
